sn35.132:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahākaccāno avantīsu viharati makkarakate araññakuṭikāyaṃ.
sn35.132:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis in a wilderness hut near Makkarakaṭa.
sn35.132:1.1.comm: Mahākaccāna was the first major Buddhist figure in the region, and evidently his presence challenged the local brahmins. The fact that he was a brahmin by birth was salt on the wound, prompting a jibe by the callow students.

sn35.132:1.2.pli: Atha kho lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa sambahulā antevāsikā kaṭṭhahārakā māṇavakā yenāyasmato mahākaccānassa araññakuṭikā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā parito parito kuṭikāya anucaṅkamanti anuvicaranti uccāsaddā mahāsaddā kānici kānici seleyyakāni karonti:
sn35.132:1.2.eng: Then several students, pupils of the brahmin Lohicca, approached Mahākaccāna’s wilderness hut while collecting firewood. They walked and wandered all around the hut, making a colossal racket and all kinds of jeers:
sn35.132:1.2.comm: A certain brahmin Lohicca also appears in DN 12. But since this discourse is set far away in Avantī after the Buddha’s passing, and since in both cases he is said to have taken refuge, it seems likely these are different people. | The term seleyyaka (variant selissaka) is unique and its meaning unclear. The commentary explains it as a kind of game like leapfrog, but contextually the sense “jeer” is more cohesive. Perhaps it is related to Sanskrit śālaka, “jester, buffon”.

sn35.132:1.3.pli: “ime pana muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kaṇhā bandhupādāpaccā, imesaṃ bharatakānaṃ sakkatā garukatā mānitā pūjitā apacitā”ti.
sn35.132:1.3.eng: “These shavelings, fake ascetics, primitives, black spawn from the feet of our kinsman, the Lord! They’re honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by so-called inheritors of Vedic culture.”
sn35.132:1.3.comm: Bharataka here is unique and its sense debatable. The commentary says they were local householders; but the context is the intrusion of Buddhism into territory dominated by Vedic ritualism. In the Rig Veda, the Bharatas were the clan ruled by King Sudās, who, blessed by Agni, the “fire of the Bharatas”, and allied with the Vāsiṣṭhas, overcame the armies of ten kings to dominate the Aryan coalition. Wijesekera has argued that bhara in this context originally meant the “booty” or “plunder” gained by raiding villages and towns (Buddhist and Vedic Studies, ch. 19). A bhārata was a descendant of the tribe, and with their cultural ascendance became a term for all Vedists. Later it became generalized; the Jain Triṣaṣṭiśalākāpuruṣacaritra of the 12th century says that Bhāratakas include all Indians, whether Aryan or not (3.29). The Pali form bharataka could here be simply a variation of bhārata in the sense “Aryan”, but the suffix -ka is often diminutive if not contemptuous (eg. samaṇaka, muṇḍaka). Compare Rig Veda 3.53.24, which appears to criticize false Bhāratas as betrayers of Vedic culture.

sn35.132:1.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākaccāno vihārā nikkhamitvā te māṇavake etadavoca:
sn35.132:1.4.eng: Then Mahākaccāna left his dwelling and said to those young students,

sn35.132:1.6.eng: I will speak to you on the teaching.”

sn35.132:1.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te māṇavakā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
sn35.132:1.7.eng: When this was said, the young students fell silent.

sn35.132:1.8.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākaccāno te māṇavake gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn35.132:1.8.eng: Then Mahākaccāna recited these verses for them.
sn35.132:1.8.comm: Similar accounts of pure, meditative Brahmans of the past and their present fallen state are at Snp 2.7 and DN 27:22.1. Buddhists argued that the real brahmins lived much like Buddhist mendicants.

sn35.132:2.2.comm: Purāṇa (“ancient”) is familiar as the name for the class of lengthy scriptures that gather legends and other forms of the traditional knowledge. As we have them today, they have undergone extensive development, but they draw on ancient sources. In Pali these are normally called itihāsa (“testaments”; see note on MN 91:2.1), and elsewhere we find purāṇa in this sense only in the late canon (Mil 5.3.7:6.1). However, pre-Buddhist texts refer to itihāsa along with purāṇa  (Atharva Veda 15.6.10, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.6.8, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.10, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 3.4.1). Given the context, it is likely this is the meaning here.

sn35.132:2.3.eng: Their sense doors were guarded, well protected,

sn35.132:3.1.pli: Dhamme ca jhāne ca ratā ahesuṃ,
sn35.132:3.1.eng: Those brahmins who remembered <j>the ancient legends

sn35.132:4.1.eng: But these have lost their way. <j>Saying, “We must recite”,
sn35.132:4.1.comm: Japāmase is middle plural imperative. The sense is that they prioritize recitation as their core duty while neglecting conduct.

sn35.132:4.2.eng: they live out of balance, judging by clan.

sn35.132:4.3.eng: Mastered by anger, they take up many arms,
sn35.132:4.3.comm: The true brahmin does not take up arms (Snp 3.9:42.2, Dhp 406).

sn35.132:4.4.eng: indifferent to those with craving and without.
sn35.132:4.4.comm: PTS and BJT read virajjhamānā tasathāvaresu (“attacking both the strong and the weak”). This appears to be a normalization, as the commentary supports MS virajjamānā sataṇhātaṇhesu. The point is that in their rage they did not even spare holy men.

sn35.132:5.1.eng: All is vain for someone <j>who doesn’t guard the sense doors,

sn35.132:5.2.eng: like the wealth a person finds in a dream.

sn35.132:5.3.comm: Compare the longer description of Vedic rites at MN 51:10.3. | “Fasting” (anāsakā) was undertaken in preparation for the ritual (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 9.5.1.6). | The thaṇḍila (Sanskrit sthaṇḍila) was the ground cleared behind the fire altar (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.2.7, Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka 9.8). The sponsor, having performed the ritual, lies on the bare ground or on a hide. If he sees a woman in his dreams, he knows his wish will be fulfilled.

sn35.132:5.4.eng: bathing at daybreak, the three Vedas,
sn35.132:5.4.comm: Pāto sinānaṁ (“bathing at daybreak”) is recorded as a Brahmanical practice also at SN 7.21:1.5; bathing three times is one of the austere practices (MN 12:45.12; cf. Kd 1:20.15.1). A brahmin was to bathe at dawn and evening before reciting the Gāyatrī (Manu 4.93, Garuḍa Purāṇa 229).

sn35.132:6.1.comm: The hide was typically that of the black antelope. | “Mud” seems out of place, as we have already seen they are concerned with bathing, and going unwashed was a Jain practice. But perhaps it is deliberately incoherent.

sn35.132:6.2.eng: hymns, precepts and observances, <j>and fervent austerities,

sn35.132:6.3.comm: “Fawning” (kuhana) is using dissembling and blandishments to obtain favor from the wealthy.

sn35.132:6.4.comm: Before and after rituals and meal, a little water was cupped in the hand and sipped.

sn35.132:6.6.eng: are only used to generate profits.
sn35.132:6.6.comm: See Bodhi Connected Discourses for a note on this line.

sn35.132:7.4.eng: that’s the path to attainment of divinity!”

sn35.132:8.1.pli: Atha kho te māṇavakā kupitā anattamanā yena lohicco brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā lohiccaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn35.132:8.1.eng: Then those young students, offended and upset, went to the brahmin Lohicca and said to him,

sn35.132:8.2.pli: “yagghe bhavaṃ jāneyya, samaṇo mahākaccāno brāhmaṇānaṃ mante ekaṃsena apavadati, paṭikkosatī”ti?
sn35.132:8.2.eng: “Please, master, you should know this. The ascetic Mahākaccāna condemns and rejects outright the hymns of the brahmins!”

sn35.132:8.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, lohicco brāhmaṇo kupito ahosi anattamano.
sn35.132:8.3.eng: When they said this, Lohicca was offended and upset.

sn35.132:8.5.pli: “na kho pana metaṃ patirūpaṃ yohaṃ aññadatthu māṇavakānaṃyeva sutvā samaṇaṃ mahākaccānaṃ akkoseyyaṃ paribhāseyyaṃ.
sn35.132:8.5.eng: “But it wouldn’t be appropriate for me to abuse or insult the ascetic Mahākaccāna solely because of what I’ve heard from these young students.

sn35.132:8.6.eng: Why don’t I go and ask him about it?”

sn35.132:9.1.pli: Atha kho lohicco brāhmaṇo tehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ yenāyasmā mahākaccāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā mahākaccānena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn35.132:9.1.eng: Then the brahmin Lohicca together with those young students went to Venerable Mahākaccāna and exchanged greetings with him.

sn35.132:9.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho lohicco brāhmaṇo āyasmantaṃ mahākaccānaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.132:9.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to him,

sn35.132:9.3.pli: “āgamaṃsu nu khvidha, bho kaccāna, amhākaṃ sambahulā antevāsikā kaṭṭhahārakā māṇavakā”ti?
sn35.132:9.3.eng: “Master Kaccāna, did several young pupils of mine come by here collecting firewood?”

sn35.132:9.4.pli: “Āgamaṃsu khvidha te, brāhmaṇa, sambahulā antevāsikā kaṭṭhahārakā māṇavakā”ti.

sn35.132:9.5.pli: “Ahu pana bhoto kaccānassa tehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
sn35.132:9.5.eng: “But did you have some discussion with them?”

sn35.132:9.6.pli: “Ahu kho me, brāhmaṇa, tehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti.

sn35.132:9.7.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana bhoto kaccānassa tehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ ahosi kathāsallāpo”ti?
sn35.132:9.7.eng: “But what kind of discussion did you have with them?”

sn35.132:9.8.pli: “Evaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, tehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ ahosi kathāsallāpo:
sn35.132:9.8.eng: “This is the discussion I had with these young students.” And he repeated the verses in full.

sn35.132:11.1.pli: Evaṃ kho me, brāhmaṇa, tehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ ahosi kathāsallāpo”ti.

sn35.132:12.1.eng: “Worthy Kaccāna spoke of someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors.

sn35.132:12.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bho kaccāna, aguttadvāro hotī”ti?
sn35.132:12.2.eng: How do you define someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors?”

sn35.132:12.3.pli: “Idha, brāhmaṇa, ekacco cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā piyarūpe rūpe adhimuccati, appiyarūpe rūpe byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati, parittacetaso
sn35.132:12.3.eng: “Brahmin, take someone who sees a sight with their eyes. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart stunted.

sn35.132:12.4.pli: tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
sn35.132:12.4.eng: And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

sn35.132:12.5.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

sn35.132:12.6.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

sn35.132:12.7.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

sn35.132:12.8.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

sn35.132:12.9.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme adhimuccati, appiyarūpe ca dhamme byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati, parittacetaso
sn35.132:12.9.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, if it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and a limited heart.

sn35.132:12.10.pli: tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
sn35.132:12.10.eng: And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

sn35.132:12.11.eng: That’s how someone doesn’t guard the sense doors.”

sn35.132:12.13.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ bhotā kaccānena aguttadvārova samāno aguttadvāroti akkhāto.
sn35.132:12.13.eng: How accurately you’ve explained someone whose sense doors are unguarded!

sn35.132:13.1.eng: You also spoke of someone who does guard the sense doors.

sn35.132:13.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bho kaccāna, guttadvāro hotī”ti?
sn35.132:13.2.eng: How do you define someone who does guard the sense doors?”

sn35.132:13.3.pli: “Idha, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā piyarūpe rūpe nādhimuccati, appiyarūpe rūpe na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati, appamāṇacetaso
sn35.132:13.3.eng: “Brahmin, take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.

sn35.132:13.4.pli: tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
sn35.132:13.4.eng: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

sn35.132:13.5.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

sn35.132:13.6.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

sn35.132:13.7.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

sn35.132:13.8.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

sn35.132:13.9.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme nādhimuccati, appiyarūpe dhamme na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati, appamāṇacetaso
sn35.132:13.9.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, if it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.

sn35.132:13.10.pli: tañca cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
sn35.132:13.10.eng: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

sn35.132:13.11.eng: That’s how someone guards the sense doors.”

sn35.132:14.2.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ bhotā kaccānena guttadvārova samāno guttadvāroti akkhāto.
sn35.132:14.2.eng: How accurately you’ve explained someone whose sense doors are guarded!

sn35.132:14.3.pli: Abhikkantaṃ, bho kaccāna; abhikkantaṃ, bho kaccāna.

sn35.132:14.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho kaccāna, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā kaccānena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn35.132:14.4.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Kaccāna has made the teaching clear in many ways.

sn35.132:14.5.pli: Esāhaṃ, bho kaccāna, taṃ bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn35.132:14.5.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn35.132:14.6.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ kaccāno dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ.
sn35.132:14.6.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.

sn35.132:14.7.pli: Yathā ca bhavaṃ kaccāno makkarakate upāsakakulāni upasaṅkamati; evameva lohiccakulaṃ upasaṅkamatu.
sn35.132:14.7.eng: Please come to my family just as you go to the families of the lay followers in Makkarakaṭa.

sn35.132:14.8.pli: Tattha ye māṇavakā vā māṇavikā vā bhavantaṃ kaccānaṃ abhivādessanti paccuṭṭhissanti āsanaṃ vā udakaṃ vā dassanti, tesaṃ taṃ bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
sn35.132:14.8.eng: The brahmin boys and girls there will bow to you, rise in your presence, and give you a seat and water. That will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

sn35.133:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā udāyī kāmaṇḍāyaṃ viharati todeyyassa brāhmaṇassa ambavane.
sn35.133:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Udāyī was staying near Kāmaṇḍā in the brahmin Todeyya’s mango grove.

sn35.133:1.2.pli: Atha kho verahaccānigottāya brāhmaṇiyā antevāsī māṇavako yenāyasmā udāyī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā udāyinā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn35.133:1.2.eng: Then a boy who was a pupil of the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan went up to Udāyī and exchanged greetings with him.
sn35.133:1.2.comm: It is unusual, if not unique, to see a female brahmin with a student. Below, she is referred to as the “tutor’s wife” (ācariyabhariyā); compare Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.10, where a tutor’s wife (ācāryajāyā) discusses the education of the pupil with her husband. Verahaccāni is not an attested clan name, and Sanskrit vairahatya means “manslaughter”. Given that her husband is rather mysteriously absent, perhaps verahaccāni is a term for brahmin ladies whose husbands were murdered. Compare nirvīrā, a woman whose husband and children are dead. If so, it would seem that she did not merely survive her husband’s passing, but stepped into his role as teacher.

sn35.133:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn35.133:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

sn35.133:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho taṃ māṇavakaṃ āyasmā udāyī dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
sn35.133:1.4.eng: Udāyī educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired that young student with a Dhamma talk.

sn35.133:1.5.pli: Atha kho so māṇavako āyasmatā udāyinā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito uṭṭhāyāsanā yena verahaccānigottā brāhmaṇī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā verahaccānigottaṃ brāhmaṇiṃ etadavoca:
sn35.133:1.5.eng: Then that young student went to the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan and said to her,

sn35.133:1.7.pli: Samaṇo udāyī dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ, sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetī”ti.
sn35.133:1.7.eng: The ascetic Udāyī proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.”

sn35.133:2.1.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, māṇavaka, mama vacanena samaṇaṃ udāyiṃ nimantehi svātanāya bhattenā”ti.
sn35.133:2.1.eng: “Then, young student, invite him in my name for tomorrow’s meal.”

sn35.133:2.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhotī”ti kho so māṇavako verahaccānigottāya brāhmaṇiyā paṭissutvā yenāyasmā udāyī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
sn35.133:2.2.eng: “Yes, madam,” he replied. He went to Udāyī and said,

sn35.133:2.3.pli: “adhivāsetu kira, bhavaṃ udāyī amhākaṃ ācariyabhariyāya verahaccānigottāya brāhmaṇiyā svātanāya bhattan”ti.
sn35.133:2.3.eng: “Sir, might the worthy Udāyī please accept an offering of tomorrow’s meal from my tutor’s wife, the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan.”

sn35.133:2.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā udāyī tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena verahaccānigottāya brāhmaṇiyā nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn35.133:2.5.eng: Then when the night had passed, Udāyī robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the brahmin lady’s home, and sat down on the seat spread out.

sn35.133:2.6.pli: Atha kho verahaccānigottā brāhmaṇī āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
sn35.133:2.6.eng: Then the brahmin lady served and satisfied Udāyī with her own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

sn35.133:2.7.pli: Atha kho verahaccānigottā brāhmaṇī āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ pādukā ārohitvā ucce āsane nisīditvā sīsaṃ oguṇṭhitvā āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
sn35.133:2.7.eng: When Udāyī had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, she put on a pair of slippers, sat on a high seat, covered her head, and said to him,
sn35.133:2.7.comm: She adopts these as signifiers of status. Perhaps as a woman she felt the need to assert her status. Nonetheless, the rules of training forbid monastics from teaching someone wearing slippers (Bu Sk 61), sitting on a high seat (Bu Sk 69), or with head covered (Bu Sk 67).

sn35.133:2.9.eng: “There will be an occasion for that, sister,” he replied, then got up from his seat and left.

sn35.133:3.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho so māṇavako yenāyasmā udāyī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā udāyinā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn35.133:3.1.eng: For a second time that young student went to Venerable Udāyī …

sn35.133:3.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.

sn35.133:3.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho taṃ māṇavakaṃ āyasmā udāyī dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.

sn35.133:3.4.pli: Dutiyampi kho so māṇavako āyasmatā udāyinā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito uṭṭhāyāsanā yena verahaccānigottā brāhmaṇī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā verahaccānigottaṃ brāhmaṇiṃ etadavoca:
sn35.133:3.4.eng: And for a second time that young student went to the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan …

sn35.133:3.6.pli: Samaṇo udāyī dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ, sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetī”ti.

sn35.133:4.1.pli: “Evamevaṃ pana tvaṃ, māṇavaka, samaṇassa udāyissa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsasi.
sn35.133:4.1.eng: She said to him, “You keep praising the ascetic Udāyī like this.

sn35.133:4.2.pli: Samaṇo panudāyī ‘bhaṇa, samaṇa, dhamman’ti vutto samāno ‘bhavissati, bhagini, samayo’ti vatvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti.
sn35.133:4.2.eng: But when I asked him to preach the Dhamma he just said that there would be an occasion for that, and then he got up and left.”

sn35.133:4.3.pli: “Tathā hi pana tvaṃ, bhoti, pādukā ārohitvā ucce āsane nisīditvā sīsaṃ oguṇṭhitvā etadavoca:
sn35.133:4.3.eng: “Madam, that’s because you put on a pair of slippers, sat on a high seat, and covered your head before inviting him to teach.

sn35.133:4.5.eng: For the good fellows respect the teaching.”

sn35.133:4.6.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, māṇavaka, mama vacanena samaṇaṃ udāyiṃ nimantehi svātanāya bhattenā”ti.
sn35.133:4.6.eng: “Then, young student, invite him in my name for tomorrow’s meal.”

sn35.133:4.7.pli: “Evaṃ, bhotī”ti kho so māṇavako verahaccānigottāya brāhmaṇiyā paṭissutvā yenāyasmā udāyī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:

sn35.133:4.8.pli: “adhivāsetu kira bhavaṃ udāyī amhākaṃ ācariyabhariyāya verahaccānigottāya brāhmaṇiyā svātanāya bhattan”ti.

sn35.133:5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā udāyī tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena verahaccānigottāya brāhmaṇiyā nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.

sn35.133:5.2.pli: Atha kho verahaccānigottā brāhmaṇī āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
sn35.133:5.2.eng: Then the brahmin lady served and satisfied Udāyī with her own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

sn35.133:5.3.pli: Atha kho verahaccānigottā brāhmaṇī āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ pādukā orohitvā nīce āsane nisīditvā sīsaṃ vivaritvā āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
sn35.133:5.3.eng: When Udāyī had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, she took off her slippers, sat on a low seat, uncovered her head, and said to him,

sn35.133:5.4.pli: “kismiṃ nu kho, bhante, sati arahanto sukhadukkhaṃ paññapenti, kismiṃ asati arahanto sukhadukkhaṃ na paññapentī”ti?
sn35.133:5.4.eng: “Sir, when what exists do the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain? When what doesn’t exist do the perfected ones not declare that there is pleasure and pain?”

sn35.133:6.1.pli: “Cakkhusmiṃ kho, bhagini, sati arahanto sukhadukkhaṃ paññapenti, cakkhusmiṃ asati arahanto sukhadukkhaṃ na paññapenti …pe…
sn35.133:6.1.eng: “Sister, when there’s an eye, the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain. When there’s no eye, the perfected ones don’t declare that there is pleasure and pain.

sn35.133:6.2.pli: jivhāya sati arahanto sukhadukkhaṃ paññapenti, jivhāya asati arahanto sukhadukkhaṃ na paññapenti …pe….
sn35.133:6.2.eng: When there’s an ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.133:6.3.pli: Manasmiṃ sati arahanto sukhadukkhaṃ paññapenti, manasmiṃ asati arahanto sukhadukkhaṃ na paññapentī”ti.
sn35.133:6.3.eng: mind, the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain. When there’s no mind, the perfected ones don’t declare that there is pleasure and pain.”

sn35.133:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, verahaccānigottā brāhmaṇī āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
sn35.133:7.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin lady said to Udāyī,

sn35.133:7.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ ayyena udāyinā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn35.133:7.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, Master Udāyī has made the teaching clear in many ways.

sn35.133:7.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, ayya udāyi, taṃ bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn35.133:7.4.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn35.133:7.5.pli: Upāsikaṃ maṃ ayyo udāyī dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn35.133:7.5.eng: From this day forth, may Master Udāyī remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn35.134:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati devadahaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo.
sn35.134:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Devadaha.

sn35.134:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn35.134:1.3.pli: “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbesaṃyeva bhikkhūnaṃ chasu phassāyatanesu appamādena karaṇīyanti vadāmi, na ca panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbesaṃyeva bhikkhūnaṃ chasu phassāyatanesu nāppamādena karaṇīyanti vadāmi.
sn35.134:1.3.eng: “When it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants, I don’t say that all mendicants have work to do with diligence, nor do I say that none of them have work to do with diligence.

sn35.134:1.4.pli: Ye te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tesāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ chasu phassāyatanesu nāppamādena karaṇīyanti vadāmi.
sn35.134:1.4.eng: I say that, when it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants don’t have work to do with diligence if they are perfected, with defilements ended, having completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and become rightly freed through enlightenment.

sn35.134:1.6.pli: Kataṃ tesaṃ appamādena, abhabbā te pamajjituṃ.
sn35.134:1.6.eng: They’ve done their work with diligence, and are incapable of negligence.

sn35.134:1.7.pli: Ye ca kho te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū sekkhā appattamānasā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānā viharanti, tesāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ chasu phassāyatanesu appamādena karaṇīyanti vadāmi.
sn35.134:1.7.eng: I say that, when it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants do have work to do with diligence if they are trainees, who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

sn35.134:1.9.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā manoramāpi, amanoramāpi.
sn35.134:1.9.eng: There are sights known by the eye that are pleasant and also those that are unpleasant.

sn35.134:1.10.pli: Tyāssa phussa phussa cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
sn35.134:1.10.eng: Though experiencing them again and again they don’t occupy the mind.

sn35.134:1.11.pli: Cetaso apariyādānā āraddhaṃ hoti vīriyaṃ asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggaṃ.
sn35.134:1.11.eng: Their energy is roused up and unflagging, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is immersed in samādhi and unified.

sn35.134:1.12.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appamādaphalaṃ sampassamāno tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ chasu phassāyatanesu appamādena karaṇīyanti vadāmi …pe…
sn35.134:1.12.eng: Seeing this fruit of diligence, I say that those mendicants have work to do with diligence when it comes to the six fields of contact. …

sn35.134:1.13.pli: santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā manoramāpi amanoramāpi.
sn35.134:1.13.eng: There are ideas known by the mind that are pleasant and also those that are unpleasant.

sn35.134:1.14.pli: Tyāssa phussa phussa cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
sn35.134:1.14.eng: Though experiencing them again and again they don’t occupy the mind.

sn35.134:1.15.pli: Cetaso apariyādānā āraddhaṃ hoti vīriyaṃ asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggaṃ.
sn35.134:1.15.eng: Their energy is roused up and unflagging, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is immersed in samādhi and unified.

sn35.134:1.16.pli: Imaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, appamādaphalaṃ sampassamāno tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ chasu phassāyatanesu appamādena karaṇīyanti vadāmī”ti.
sn35.134:1.16.eng: Seeing this fruit of diligence, I say that those mendicants have work to do with diligence when it comes to the six fields of contact.”

sn35.135:1.2.eng: to have the opportunity to lead the spiritual life.

sn35.135:1.3.pli: Diṭṭhā mayā, bhikkhave, chaphassāyatanikā nāma nirayā.
sn35.135:1.3.eng: I’ve seen the hell named ‘Related to the Six Fields of Contact’.
sn35.135:1.3.comm: According to MN 50:22.2, this is a name for the Great Hell. It is, therefore, a literal name for hell, not a metaphor for hell as nothing more than sense experience. The hell called “The Mighty Fever” is described in similar terms at SN 56.43.

sn35.135:1.4.pli: Tattha yaṃ kiñci cakkhunā rūpaṃ passati aniṭṭharūpaṃyeva passati, no iṭṭharūpaṃ; akantarūpaṃyeva passati, no kantarūpaṃ; amanāparūpaṃyeva passati, no manāparūpaṃ.
sn35.135:1.4.eng: There, whatever sight you see with your eye is unlikable, not likable; undesirable, not desirable; unpleasant, not pleasant.

sn35.135:1.9.pli: yaṃ kiñci manasā dhammaṃ vijānāti aniṭṭharūpaṃyeva vijānāti, no iṭṭharūpaṃ; akantarūpaṃyeva vijānāti, no kantarūpaṃ; amanāparūpaṃyeva vijānāti, no manāparūpaṃ.
sn35.135:1.9.eng: Whatever idea you know with your mind is unlikable, not likable; undesirable, not desirable; unpleasant, not pleasant.

sn35.135:1.10.pli: Lābhā vo, bhikkhave, suladdhaṃ vo, bhikkhave,
sn35.135:1.10.eng: You’re fortunate, mendicants, so very fortunate,

sn35.135:1.11.eng: to have the opportunity to lead the spiritual life.

sn35.135:1.12.pli: Diṭṭhā mayā, bhikkhave, chaphassāyatanikā nāma saggā.
sn35.135:1.12.eng: I’ve seen the heaven called ‘Related to the Six Fields of Contact’.

sn35.135:1.13.pli: Tattha yaṃ kiñci cakkhunā rūpaṃ passati iṭṭharūpaṃyeva passati, no aniṭṭharūpaṃ; kantarūpaṃyeva passati, no akantarūpaṃ; manāparūpaṃyeva passati, no amanāparūpaṃ …pe…
sn35.135:1.13.eng: There, whatever sight you see with your eye is likable, not unlikable; desirable, not undesirable; pleasant, not unpleasant.

sn35.135:1.15.pli: yaṃ kiñci manasā dhammaṃ vijānāti iṭṭharūpaṃyeva vijānāti, no aniṭṭharūpaṃ; kantarūpaṃyeva vijānāti, no akantarūpaṃ; manāparūpaṃyeva vijānāti, no amanāparūpaṃ.
sn35.135:1.15.eng: Whatever idea you know with your mind is likable, not unlikable; desirable, not undesirable; pleasant, not unpleasant.

sn35.135:1.16.pli: Lābhā vo, bhikkhave, suladdhaṃ vo, bhikkhave,
sn35.135:1.16.eng: You’re fortunate, mendicants, so very fortunate,

sn35.135:1.17.eng: to have the opportunity to lead the spiritual life.”
